awd_titl_txt: Dynamics in Random Media: from Homogenization to Stochasticity
awd_abstract_narration:
This research is devoted to understanding the effects of random perturbations on behavior of complex systems. Stochasticity abounds in physics, applied science and engineering, ranging from statistical mechanics, atmospheric science, materials engineering, oceanography and so on. There are typically various temporal or spatial scales involved in the system, and to understand the propagation of stochasticity through these scales and to control its overall impact is of crucial importance for many applications such as exploration geophysics, materials design, meteorology and weather forecasting. The main mathematical tool to model such multi-scale dynamical systems involving stochasticity is through partial differential equations (PDE) with rough random coefficients. The project aims at deriving simplified effective models of those PDE with rough random coefficients and exhibiting some general features of the mechanism of stochasticity propagation through complicated systems. 

The proposed research is in the areas of stochastic homogenization, wave in random media, and stochastic PDE. The principle investigator plans to study (i) the random fluctuations in stochastic homogenization; (ii) the effective models of wave propagation in random media; (iii) the convergence to stochastic PDE beyond the homogenization regime and the statistical properties of some singular stochastic PDE. The study will involve tools from analysis, probability and numerical methods. The educational program includes the training of graduate and undergraduate students at the intersection of probability, analysis, and applications, and the goal is to introduce students the analytic and probabilistic tools which are indispensable for both the research and the STEM-related career development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project has focused on a few prototypical models in physics and engineering, in particular models from statistical mechanics, including interface growth subjected to random perturbations, a directed polymer in a random environment, and a passive tracer in a random flow. The goal was to provide mathematically rigorous study of some qualitative and quantitative properties of these models, and to answer questions such as (i) how fast the interface grows, (ii) how large are the random fluctuations of the interface around its mean, (iii) how many turns a random directed polymer path does around a cylinder, (iv) how fast does a passive tracer moves in a random flow and how the answer depends on the correlation properties of the flow. The answers to these questions helps to improve our understanding of how stochasticities propagate across different scales and interplay with nonlinear actions. 

 

One of the findings in this project concerns the so-called replica-over of directed polymers in a random environment, namely, to study questions of how much do two independent polymer paths intersect with each other and what is the statistical properties of the mutual intersection. The obtained result shows that, in the so-called strong disorder regime where the random environment plays a crucial role, the mutual intersection self averages to some positive constant, which is itself a sign of polymer paths localization, and the random fluctuations around the mean has asymptotic Gaussian fluctuations. This is the first result on the statistical properties of polymer paths overlap, and has further shed light on the localization properties of polymer paths in the strong disorder regime. Another object of interest in this project is the so-called Kardar-Parisi-Zhang equation, which is regarded as the default model of surface growth in a random environment. The PI considered the torus geometry on which the random growth takes place and obtained a complete description of the surface behaviors in large time. It was proved rigorously that the average height of the surface has asymptotic Gaussian fluctuations, and the shape of the surface converges to the stationary distribution. The result is in sharp contrast with the case of a growth on an infinite line.   

 

During the past year of support, the PI visited multiple universities to present the obtained results, including Auburn University, University of Rochester, Stanford University, University of Utah etc. The PI organized two conferences at the University of Maryland, and supervised one female graduate student and one postdoctoral researcher. 

 

During the entire time of the award, the PI has worked on mutiple important models of physical interests and has obtained rigorous mathematical results which helped improve our understanding of the corresponding physical phenomena. In particular, the PI initiated the study of stochastic equations relevant to the interface growth on a torus geometry and provided first results on the long time behaviors of such equations. The PI has also studied geometric and statistical properties of random paths in random environments and provided precise descriptions of the random fluctuations of physical quantities such as mutual intersection, winding number etc. The award has supported the PI to visit other universities, to attend conferences and workshops to disseminate the results, to organize two conferences, and to supervise graduate students and postdoctoral researchers.
